bibl.title: Letter from the Acting Secretary of the Surgeon General to Henry Rose Carter, June 18, 1920

div1.p: The Acting Secretary informs Carter that he is being placed on waiting orders. He thanks Carter for his years of service.

div1.head: Letter from the Acting Secretary of the Surgeon General to Henry Rose Carter, June 18, 1920
div1.opener:
Copy.
L. A. C.
Treasury Department,
Washington
June 18, 1920.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Sir:
div1.p:
The Board of medical officers who examined you physically
on May 22, 1920, has recommended that you be placed on waiting
orders. This report has been approved by the Surgeon General
and in accordance with the regulations, you are hereby placed
on waiting orders at the termination of your accrued leave,
effective July 24, 1920.

In this connection it is desired to express appreciation
for the valuable service you have rendered, not only to the
Public Health Service, but the country at large, on account of
your extensive studies in the spread of yellow fever and the
proper methods to pursue in combatting and eradicating this
disease.

Your pioneer work in determining important factors in the
spread of yellow fever, especially the period of time between
the primary and secondary case in a newly infected place, furnished
the keystone for important scientific work of a later date. This
will always be a credit, both to yourself and the Public Health
Service.

Your work in connection with the eradication of malarial
fever deserves more than passing comment. The knowledge you
brought of this important Public Health work will prove of lasting
benefit. While, on account of your age and physical disabilities,
your period of active field work has passed, it is hoped that the
Public Health Service will be able to have your advice and counsel
on important Public Health problems for years to come.
